div.ab:
32. Not built from with neat red bricks, but with clods
of earth, reeds and straw, patches and fragments,
and oddly plastered and smeared,
and behind them, our blue-tinted forests
on a ground of ash, with white strokes
applied to the dry blue, for contrast.
Also dried Tree trunks, finely painted,
Bending inward, one close behind the other.
right-middleNo bright Vermilion or red lead for making roofs, but all as it is in life.

33. The smallest Trees should be stippled.
Yet before we rush to paint the foreground trees,
let us, for a while, climb the steep cliffs
where the floating clouds, with damp lips,
spray and bathe the topmost peaks.
In the main, their color is a sufficiently pale ash;
sometimes their bald tips stick up
in the middle of a dense pine forest.
right-middleCliffs, and painting all their proper colors.

34. Indeed, among the terrible rocks which fill
Switzerland and separate France from Italy,
the targets of the North wind, covered with white patches–
from these sometimes stand a few crags
that resemble clouds, with Castles below.
Here, O brushes, imitate like Echo
the roar of the waters which shoot down from above,
raging through pitted stones.

35. Observe how the stones, like icicles,
hang on the rocks in the waterfall,
green with moss and irregular without order,
the floods, as if drunk, fall in crazed courses,
lurching and twisting over lumps and bumps
to the bottom, resembling Snakes.
Look how these Mastic Trees grow
and how strangely they spread–who would ever dream it?

36. Now, to disperse the gloom, we have arrived
at the shadowy realm of the Hamadryads,
that is, the Trees, which, if painted well,
embellish and exalt all work;
or if not, they will spoil it. So I must advise
becoming accustomed to painting leaves
in a skilled and elegant manner, with one good stroke.
For all strength is here; this should be mastered.
right-middleOn trees, and dark Forests, To seek a good stroke for leaves.

div.ab:
37. Overall, one should seek out many conditions
from life, or pleasant examples,
working steadily on prepared paper
with ink and wash to paint growing leaves,
hoping to achieve it in due time.
Yet this is not like the instructive Art
of the muscled body. For leaves, hair, air, and drapery:
right-middleLeaves, hair, air and drapery are difficult to learn, being a matter of the mind.
